interlinear-text.item: A band of Indians move into the lake

phrase.item: A deer came swimming to shore.
They killed it.
Then they cooked it.
All the people who ate (of) that deer, after they had eaten, got ready.
They gathered up their blankets and so forth; they made ready.
Then they went afoot entering the lake.
They left an old woman and her nephews.
The people and so forth (the dogs too) who ate that deer’s meat and so forth, everything that had drunk of the deer’s gravy went into the lake.
They disliked the old woman.
Therefore the old woman and her nephews had not eaten that deer’s meet.
Therefore the old woman did not go with him.
If she had drunk of the deer’s gravy, she too would have gone.
When they had gone, the old woman did not know what to do.
She came back to her people.
She told them, “All the people went into the lake.”
Not believing the old woman, the people who lived here went to see how it happened that they had gone into the lake.
They met her nephews and took the old woman back with them.
When they got to (the lake) they did not see anything.
It was true that they had gone.
All the people had gone; they had left only one old woman.
Since then they beat a drum (from time to time) at the bottom of the lake.
They sing songs and so forth.
They dance at night.
Their cane torches are lit all night at the bottom of the lake.
They dance.
All night the cane torches are lit.
Nine times nine are lit.
When they light them to dance, they dance after they are lit.
When people go to the lake, (they find that) there are bits of burnt cane floating at the edge of the lake.
You see that if you go to the lake.
If you go the next day or so and if you see the burnt cane – if you see that you can expect bad weather.
That happens to tell of bad weather.
If you see that, very bad weather is coming.
It is not good to cross the lake.
I have seen that myself.
I used to play with the burnt cane when I was a boy.
It is not too long ago that I used to see the cane torches.
I have talked about that with everybody.
I have told about it plenty (of times) to White people and all.
He left his brothers.
He went and went till he came to the edge of a pond.
When he got to the edge of the pond, he swam it.
Then he went (on) again and came (again) to the edge (of a body of water).
He said, “This pond is too big for me to cross”.
Then an eagle met him.
The eagle asked, “You young man, what are you doing there?”
“I have come to the water’s side.
This pond is too big for me to swim”.
“Do you want to cross it?”, that eagle asked.
He told the eagle, “I want to cross it, but this pond is too big”.
“I’ll help you, if you wish,” the eagle said.
“I do wish it, if you can help me”.
Then they say the eagle took him up and flew toward the opposite side of the pond.
“If I get tired, I’ll have to drop you into the water,” (said the eagle).
“If you drop me back into the water I’ll swim”.
Then the eagle picked him up again.
Then he got him across.
They say that is why Indians do not kill eagles.
If one kills an eagle, he will get into some trouble.
That is how Indians came across (to) this side.
I do not know how people started up, but that is how the man came over here.
Nobody knows how people started up.
That is all now.
